articles.headline: In a Shift, AOL Mail to Be Free
articles.snippet: The company said it would be able to cut $1 billion a year from AOL’s expenses and increase its advertising sales on an expanded line of free Web-based services.
articles.abstract: The company said it would be able to cut $1 billion a year from AOL’s expenses and increase its advertising sales on an expanded line of free Web-based services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time Warner yesterday outlined a radical plan to revive AOL by making more money with far fewer subscribers.
articles.byline: By Saul Hansell and Richard Siklos

articles.headline: Civilians Lose as Fighters Slip Into Fog of War
articles.snippet: Civilian deaths illustrate the difficulty of fighting militias that fire rockets from family gardens, orchards and village streets.
articles.abstract: Civilian deaths illustrate the difficulty of fighting militias that fire rockets from family gardens, orchards and village streets.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYRE, Lebanon, Aug. 2 — On a mountain road just south of here, a convoy of Lebanese villagers was fleeing north shortly after the war began. They had heard Israeli soldiers telling them to evacuate. Suddenly, a rocket struck a pickup truck full of people. Twenty-one people were killed, more than half of them children.

articles.headline: In Iraq, It’s Hard to Trust Anyone in Uniform
articles.snippet: Iraqis have become suspicious and fearful of men dressed as those who are supposed to protect and serve.
articles.abstract: Iraqis have become suspicious and fearful of men dressed as those who are supposed to protect and serve.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 2 — The camouflaged Iraqi commandos who kidnapped 20 people from a pair of central Baghdad offices this week used Interior Ministry vehicles and left little trace of their true identities.

articles.headline: Energy From the Restless Sea
articles.snippet: Machines of various shapes and sizes are being tested off shores around the world to see how they capture waves and tides and create marine energy.
articles.abstract: Machines of various shapes and sizes are being tested off shores around the world to see how they capture waves and tides and create marine energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWCASTLE, England — There is more riding the waves here than surfers, thanks to a growing number of scientists, engineers and investors.

articles.headline: Senate Bill Lifts Hopes of Big Oil Offshore
articles.snippet: Both houses of Congress have now passed legislation on new exploration, and any final version is expected to liberalize offshore drilling for the oil companies.
articles.abstract: Both houses of Congress have now passed legislation on new exploration, and any final version is expected to liberalize offshore drilling for the oil companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big oil has been pressing Congress for years to expand its rights to drill for domestic offshore oil and gas, with little to show for its efforts. But with tensions in the Middle East and gasoline prices at home rising, the industry’s fortunes on Capitol Hill may be changing.

articles.headline: A Bill Payer Falls Behind, Like Clients
articles.snippet: Customers of CheckFree skipped payments, its revenue fell and shares followed suit.
articles.abstract: Customers of CheckFree skipped payments, its revenue fell and shares followed suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, the company had a problem.

articles.headline: 200 Missiles Hit Israel as Battle Rages in Lebanon
articles.snippet: At the U.N., France, Britain and the U.S. said they were nearing agreement on an international force that would take over control of the buffer zone.
articles.abstract: At the U.N., France, Britain and the U.S. said they were nearing agreement on an international force that would take over control of the buffer zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 2 — Hezbollah guerrillas fired the largest number of rockets yet into Israel — more than 200 — on Wednesday as thousands of Israeli troops faced fierce fighting in Lebanon, and sought to establish a buffer zone under their control.
articles.byline: By John Kifner and Warren Hoge

articles.headline: Cubans in U.S. Feel the Tug of Two Homes
articles.snippet: Many Cuban immigrants originally planned to return, but after nearly 50 years, Miami has become home.
articles.abstract: Many Cuban immigrants originally planned to return, but after nearly 50 years, Miami has become home.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Aug. 2 — When Pelayo Duran left Cuba, he had only the clothes on his back and a cigar. He prospered in the United States, not so much with money, but with something more precious: an education for his children, who are now professionals.
articles.byline: By David Gonzalez and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: In Iraq, Its Hard to Trust Anyone in Uniform
articles.snippet: The camouflaged Iraqi commandos who kidnapped 20 people from a pair of central Baghdad offices this week used Interior Ministry vehicles and left little trace of their true identities.      Were they legitimate officers? Members of a Shiite or Sun...
articles.abstract: The camouflaged Iraqi commandos who kidnapped 20 people from a pair of central Baghdad offices this week used Interior Ministry vehicles and left little trace of their true identities.      Were they legitimate officers? Members of a Shiite or Sunni death squad? Or criminals in counterfeit uniforms bought at the market?
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 2 - The camouflaged Iraqi commandos who kidnapped 20 people from a pair of central Baghdad offices this week used Interior Ministry vehicles and left little trace of their true identities.

articles.headline: Senate Bill Lifts Hopes of Big Oil Offshore
articles.snippet: Big oil has been pressing Congress for years to expand its rights to drill for domestic offshore oil and gas, with little to show for its efforts. But with tensions in the Middle East and gasoline prices at home rising, the industry's fortunes on ...
articles.abstract: Big oil has been pressing Congress for years to expand its rights to drill for domestic offshore oil and gas, with little to show for its efforts. But with tensions in the Middle East and gasoline prices at home rising, the industry's fortunes on Capitol Hill may be changing.     Both houses of Congress have now passed legislation on new exploration, and though the bills differ, any final version is expected to liberalize offshore drilling for the oil companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big oil has been pressing Congress for years to expand its rights to drill for domestic offshore oil and gas, with little to show for its efforts. But with tensions in the Middle East and gasoline prices at home rising, the industry's fortunes on Capitol Hill may be changing.

articles.headline: Cubans in U.S. Feel the Tug of Two Homes
articles.snippet: When Pelayo Duran left Cuba, he had only the clothes on his back and a cigar. He prospered in the United States, not so much with money, but with something more precious: an education for his children, who are now professionals.      Still, like m...
articles.abstract: When Pelayo Duran left Cuba, he had only the clothes on his back and a cigar. He prospered in the United States, not so much with money, but with something more precious: an education for his children, who are now professionals.      Still, like many other Cubans who fled the island, Miami was only supposed to be a stopover for Mr. Duran and his wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Aug. 2 - When Pelayo Duran left Cuba, he had only the clothes on his back and a cigar. He prospered in the United States, not so much with money, but with something more precious: an education for his children, who are now professionals.
articles.byline: By David Gonzalez and Abby Goodnough

articles.abstract: David Pogue, whose column for Circuits normally appears on this page, is on vacation.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Pogue, whose column for Circuits normally appears on this page, is on vacation.

articles.headline: A Long-Term Battle To Define 'Victory'
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert wants to ensure that when a cease-fire is finally arranged, Israel is seen as having won a decisive victory over Hezbollah. Israel also wants to send a message to the Palestinians, and to Hezbollah and its sponsors, Syri...
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert wants to ensure that when a cease-fire is finally arranged, Israel is seen as having won a decisive victory over Hezbollah. Israel also wants to send a message to the Palestinians, and to Hezbollah and its sponsors, Syria and Iran.     But the battle of perceptions is not so easily won, especially when all Hezbollah needs to declare itself victorious is to avoid defeat. The surest signs of success, in Israel's eyes, would be achieving the ability to alter Hezbollah's decision-making or to have the group dismantled.      News analysis, Page A10.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert wants to ensure that when a cease-fire is finally arranged, Israel is seen as having won a decisive victory over Hezbollah. Israel also wants to send a message to the Palestinians, and to Hezbollah and its sponsors, Syria and Iran.

articles.headline: In a Shift, AOL Mail to Be Free
articles.snippet: Time Warner yesterday outlined a radical plan to revive AOL by making more money with far fewer subscribers.      AOL will stop marketing its highly profitable Internet access service and offer most of its main features free. As a result, it expec...
articles.abstract: Time Warner yesterday outlined a radical plan to revive AOL by making more money with far fewer subscribers.      AOL will stop marketing its highly profitable Internet access service and offer most of its main features free. As a result, it expects to lose more than half of its 17.7 million subscribers over the next three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time Warner yesterday outlined a radical plan to revive AOL by making more money with far fewer subscribers.
articles.byline: By Saul Hansell and Richard Siklos

articles.headline: A Bill Payer Falls Behind, Like Clients
articles.snippet: In April, the company had a problem.     In June, the chief executive sold $16 million of stock.
articles.abstract: In April, the company had a problem.     In June, the chief executive sold $16 million of stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, the company had a problem.

articles.headline: Civilians Lose as Fighters Slip Into Fog of War
articles.snippet: On a mountain road just south of here, a convoy of Lebanese villagers was fleeing north shortly after the war began. They had heard Israeli soldiers telling them to evacuate. Suddenly, a rocket struck a pickup truck full of people. Twenty-one peop...
articles.abstract: On a mountain road just south of here, a convoy of Lebanese villagers was fleeing north shortly after the war began. They had heard Israeli soldiers telling them to evacuate. Suddenly, a rocket struck a pickup truck full of people. Twenty-one people were killed, more than half of them children.      Israel said it believed the convoy was transporting rockets. The convoy had not notified Israel that it was going to make the trip. Those who survived said in interviews that they were simply following Israeli orders to flee the south as best they could.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYRE, Lebanon, Aug. 2 - On a mountain road just south of here, a convoy of Lebanese villagers was fleeing north shortly after the war began. They had heard Israeli soldiers telling them to evacuate. Suddenly, a rocket struck a pickup truck full of people. Twenty-one people were killed, more than half of them children.

articles.headline: Energy From the Restless Sea
articles.snippet: There is more riding the waves here than surfers, thanks to a growing number of scientists, engineers and investors.      A group of entrepreneurs is harnessing the perpetual motion of the ocean and turning it into a commodity in high demand: ener...
articles.abstract: There is more riding the waves here than surfers, thanks to a growing number of scientists, engineers and investors.      A group of entrepreneurs is harnessing the perpetual motion of the ocean and turning it into a commodity in high demand: energy. Right now, machines of various shapes and sizes are being tested off shores from the North Sea to the Pacific -- one may even be coming to the East River in New York State this fall -- to see how they capture waves and tides and create marine energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWCASTLE, England - There is more riding the waves here than surfers, thanks to a growing number of scientists, engineers and investors.

articles.headline: 200 Missiles Hit Israel as Battle Rages in Lebanon
articles.snippet: Hezbollah guerrillas fired the largest number of rockets yet into Israel -- more than 200 -- on Wednesday as thousands of Israeli troops faced fierce fighting in Lebanon, and sought to establish a buffer zone under their control.     Battles raged...
articles.abstract: Hezbollah guerrillas fired the largest number of rockets yet into Israel -- more than 200 -- on Wednesday as thousands of Israeli troops faced fierce fighting in Lebanon, and sought to establish a buffer zone under their control.     Battles raged in a half-dozen pockets, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Israel would fight until an international force moved into southern Lebanon.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 2 - Hezbollah guerrillas fired the largest number of rockets yet into Israel -- more than 200 -- on Wednesday as thousands of Israeli troops faced fierce fighting in Lebanon, and sought to establish a buffer zone under their control.
articles.byline: By John Kifner and Warren Hoge
